Yes, the original Sherlock Holmes stories have entered the public domain in most countries. The copyright on Conan Doyle's works expired in the United Kingdom in 1980, 50 years after his death, and in most other countries, the copyright has expired or will expire within a similar timeframe.

This means that the stories are now in the public domain, and anyone can freely use, adapt, or reproduce them without seeking permission from Conan Doyle's estate or paying royalties. This has led to a wide variety of adaptations and reinterpretations of the stories, from films and TV shows to stage productions and literary works.

It's worth noting, however, that some elements of the Sherlock Holmes stories may still be protected by trademark or other intellectual property rights. For example, the character of Sherlock Holmes and certain iconic elements of the stories, such as the deerstalker hat and the pipe, are trademarked and may be subject to legal protections.

Overall, while the original stories of Sherlock Holmes are now in the public domain, there may still be certain restrictions or limitations on how they can be used or adapted depending on the specific intellectual property rights involved.
